repnme.cdata!:
Albania - Financial Sector Institution
            Building Technical Assistance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome for the Financial Sector
            Institution Building Technical Assistance Project for
            Albania was satisfactory, the sustainability was highly
            likely, the institutional development impact was high, and
            the Bank and borrower performance were both satisfactory.
            Lessons learned from the project: Technical assistance
            greatly enhances the reform process, especially when it is
            in place prior to the policy-based operation. Commitment of
            the Borrower and other beneficiaries are essential in any
            project. Staffing continuity facilitates project
            implementation and the achievement of its objectives.
            Coordination with other international financial institutions
            and donors should be maintained to ensure consistency of
            approach and to avoid duplication of efforts. Technical
            assistance projects should be targeted and linked to
            specific assistance needed to advance a reform agenda but
            some flexibility in design should be maintained to respond
            to evolving needs. The careful selection of indicators and
            their relation to the desired outcome facilitates monitoring
            of progress, allows timely actions to be taken to make corrections.

repnme.cdata!:
Albania - Financial Sector Institution
            Building Technical Assistance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Financial Sector Institution
            Building Technical Assistance Project for Albania aims to
            strengthen the financial sector, focusing on the banking and
            insurance industries. There are four main project
            components. The first finances services from management
            advisors and privatization advisors, needed to privatize a
            savings bank, and funds a financial audit. The second
            component strengthens the country's financial
            infrastructure including implementing an inter-bank payments
            system; providing technical assistance to develop national
            accounting standards, revising the chart of accounts for the
            enterprise, banking, insurance sectors, and budgetary
            institutions to comply with the new law; carrying out an
            operational and financial audit of the loan collection
            agency; and establishing a credit information bureau. The
            third component supports advisory services to develop and
            implement a privatization strategy; to price and set
            reserves for third party liability and casualty/life
            insurance products; and to introduce modern claims
            management systems and skills. It also develops and
            integrates accounting and operations' information
            systems, and develops the legal and regulatory environment
            dealing with issues such as solvency and liability/asset
            management. The fourth component focuses on revising the
            legal, institutional, regulatory, and supervisory framework
            for capital markets to ensure transparency, investor
            protection, and risk reduction.
